abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The complexity of genetic variant interpretation means that a proportion of individuals who undergo genetic testing for a hereditary cancer syndrome will have their test result reclassified over time. Such a reclassification may involve a clinically significant upgrade or downgrade in pathogenicity, which may have significant implications for medical management. To date, few studies have examined the psychosocial impact of a reclassification in a hereditary cancer syndrome context. To address this gap, semi-structured telephone interviews were performed with eighteen individuals who had a <jats:italic>BRCA1</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>BRCA2</jats:italic> or Lynch syndrome-related (<jats:italic>MLH1</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>MSH2</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>MSH6</jats:italic> or <jats:italic>PMS2)</jats:italic> gene variant reclassified. The interviews were analysed utilising an inductive, qualitative approach and emergent themes were identified by thematic analysis. Variable levels of recall amongst participants were found. Common motivations for initial testing included a significant personal and/or family history of cancer and a desire to “find an answer”. No individual whose uncertain result was upgraded reported negative psychosocial outcomes; most reported adapting to their reclassified result and appraised their genetic testing experience positively. However, individuals whose likely pathogenic/pathogenic results were downgraded reported feelings of anger, shock and sadness post reclassification, highlighting that additional psychosocial support may be required for some. Genetic counselling issues and recommendations for clinical practice are outlined.</jats:p>

assertion.value: The Peter MacCallum Cancer Centre ethical review board approved the study (HREC/17/PMCC/265).

Spurdle, Paul James, Jane Fleming, Cassandra Nichols, Rachel Austin, Elisa Cops, Melissa Monnik, Judy Do and Rajneesh Kaur declare that they have no conflict of interest. Part of this work was conducted to fulfil a degree requirement for LW.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: All procedures followed were in accordance with the ethical standards of the responsible committee on human experimentation (institutional and national) and with the Helsinki Declaration of 1975, as revised in 2000 (5). Informed consent was obtained from all patients for being included in the study.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: This article does not contain any studies with human or animal subjects performed by any of the authors.

title: Exploring the impact of the reclassification of a hereditary cancer syndrome gene variant: emerging themes from a qualitative study
